section.title: Introduction
section.para: Jetty is just a Java program that you can run like any other Java program once you set up a classpath. For example, you can run the SimplestServer from the Embedding Jetty Tutorial as follows:
Similarly, if you configure your server with jetty.xml rather than with embedded style, this also is just running a Java program, but this time with the XMLConfigurator as the main:

The difficult part of both these examples is knowing what must be on the JETTY_CLASSPATH, as the Jetty server comes in many jars encapsulating an optional features. So working out exactly which Jars are needed can be difficult. If you develop with Maven, these Jar dependencies can be managed for you, but you still need to set up a classpath when running from the command line.

The Jetty start.jar mechanism is an executable Jar file that builds a class path and then executes your main program. While start.jar is a generic and can start any Java program, the default start.config file is for Jetty, so that you can start Jetty with:

The start.jar builds a classpath and executes a main java class with a classloader built from that classpath. By default the start.jar mechanism is configured to start the jetty server, but it can be configured to start any java main class.

section.title: Start Configuration
section.para: The behaviour of the start.jar mechanism is controlled by the start.config file, which has a default version for jetty built into the start.jar itself. Only in exceptional circumstances will a jetty user need to edit or replace the start.config file (with the --config=<file> command line option). However, it is the start.config file that knows about the directory layout of the jetty distribution and defines may of the properties and options that can be set to configure jetty, These are described in the next sections, but can also be discovered by listing the start.config file with the --list-config command line option and the processed start configuration can been seen with:

section.title: Start Properties
section.para: As well as building the class path, the start.jar builds an environment of start properties that are used to parameterize the configuration of jetty. For example, the jetty-http.xml file defines the HTTP port using the XML element <Property name="jetty.port" default="8080" />, so that by default port 8080 is used. But if the jetty.port property is passed to the start.jar mechanism, then the port may be changed without editing the XML configuration file:

Note that start properties exist only during the startup of the program, while System properties are available at any time during execution. System properties can be specified on either the JVM or start.jar command line with the usual -Dname=value syntax and start properties are specified on the start.config command line with just name=value syntax. When looking up start properties, if a value is not found then a System property for the same name may be used.

listitem.para: The home directory of the jetty distribution is used to as the base for other jetty start configuration. It can be set by either system property or start property, but if it is not set then a search of likely locations is performed before defaulting to the current working directory.
If set, the path property is prepended to the classpath built by start.jar
If set, the directory identified by the lib property is searched for jars to prepend to the classpath built by start.jar
If set, overrules the default main class to run.

Used to define which options the start mechanism will consider when building the classpath. The OPTIONS property is special in that if it is set multiple times then it adds the new value as a coma separated list to the old.

section.para: Note also that start options may be set by including a standard java Properties file on the command line which is named with the extension ".properties".

section.title: Start Options
section.para: Options are named collections of jars that are added to the classpath when the option name is included in the OPTIONS property. Options are defined either by being explicitly declared in the start.config file or by being discovered. The default start.config file maps the main jetty jars into some standard options and then discovers any subdirectory of $(jetty.home)/lib that contains jars as an option. The resulting options can be listed in summary with --help or in detail with --list-options.
By convention in the default start.config, options starting with capital letters (eg Server, All) are meta-options that include several other more fine grained options (eg io, util, http etc.)

section.title: Building the Classpath
section.para: The start.jar mechanism builds a classpath under the control of the start.config and the discovered and defined options. The default start.config builds the classpath from:

The property path may be used to define additional entries to be prepended to the classpath.
The property lib may be used to define an additional directory to be searched for jar files to append to the classpath.
The $(jetty.home)/resources directory is defined as a location to add resources to the classpath as used by many third party packages (eg. log4j.properties).
The known (eg jmx, jaas, setuid etc.) and discovered (eg lib/myoption) options define one or more jar files that are appended to the classpath if the option is listed in the OPTIONS property.
The $(jetty.home)/lib/ext directory is searched for additional jar files to append to the classpath.

section.title: Building the Arguments (Configurations)
section.para: Any command line argument not interpreted by start.jar is passed to the started java program as an argument. The default the start.jar mechanism runs XmlConfiguration class which interprets arguments as configuration files and property files to run. If no arguments are specified, the default of $(jetty.home)/etc/jetty.xml is used.

Jetty configuration files are additive, so that multiple configuration files can be specified for multiple features. Frequently a start option will have both an jar that needs to be set as an OPTION and a matching configuration file. The following example uses the --ini options (to disable start.ini see below) and to start a basic server with jmx option and configuration and a HTTP connector:
section.screen: > java -jar start.jar --ini OPTIONS=Server,jmx etc/jetty.xml etc/jetty-http.xml etc/jetty-jmx.xml

section.title: Running the Main
section.para: The jetty start.config has org.eclipse.jetty.xml.XmlConfiguration as the main class to run. You can replace it with another class by setting the start.class system property.

section.title: Start Defaults
section.para: The start.jar mechanism can be configured with command line options and arguments, which may need to be specified every time that jetty is run. To avoid this repetition, the start.jar mechanism supports the start.ini file and start.d directory as mechanisms to set default command line options and arguments.

section.title: The start.ini file
section.para: If the file start.ini exists in the same directory as start.jar, it is read and every non-comment line is treated as a command line argument. The following start.ini sets the options and default configuration files for using the server with JMX and SSL:
Note how the OPTIONS property is additive and both the Server and jmx options are enabled by this example.

section.title: The start.d directory
section.para: In order to support better modularisation of configuration, the start.ini file lists start.d/ as a directory that can contain other ini files that are processed in alphabetical order. For example the test login service (realm) and client option needed for the test webapp are defined in the file start.d/test-webapp.ini:
section.programlisting: # Enabled services and configuration needed by the test webapp OPTIONS=client etc/test-realm.xml

section.title: JVM arguments and --exec
section.para: As well as normal start.jar arguments, it is possible to put JVM arguments in a start.ini. However, because these cannot affect the JVM that is running start.jar, you should provide the --exec option so that a new JVM is spawned with the arguments. The following start.ini example sets the JVM heap memory and enables remote JMX management:
section.programlisting: #=========================================================== # Jetty start.jar arguments #----------------------------------------------------------- --exec -Xmx512m -XX:OnOutOfMemoryError='kill -3 %p' -Dcom.sun.management.jmxremote OPTIONS=Server,jmx,resources etc/jetty-jmx.xml etc/jetty.xml etc/jetty-ssl.xml

note.para: Note the single quotes used to specfy the commandline in -XX:OnOutOfMemoryError='kill -3 %p'. Double quotes will work for the jvm as well, but not for Jetty's commandline parser. So make sure to use single quotes for such things.
